Welcome to my site! I'm Jingwen Jiao. I received my master's degree in Statistics from the University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC) in 2024. I earned my B.Sc. degree in Statistics from the School of Statistics and Data Science at Jiangxi University of Finance and Economics in 2021(rank 1/54). I had the privilege of being academically trained under the supervision of Prof. Song Jiang and Prof. Liwei Xu.
I am a research assistant at the Environmental Research Center under the supervision of Prof. Junjie Zhang at Duke University and a visiting student in the Department of Statistics and Data Science at Southern University of Science and Technology (SUS Tech) from 2023-2024 under the supervision of Prof. Yifang Ma. I'm actively looking for Ph.D. positions in 2025 fall.

Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.

summary: Water ripples on a lake, spreading outward from the point of impact, metaphorically illustrate the influence of scientific awards within the scientific community. We quantify the “ripple effects” of awards on the impact of papers by prizewinners and their collaborators. Integrating over 3.6 million pre-award publications from 3,453 winners and their 216,587 collaborators and combining exact and yearly curve matching, we estimated the post-award spillover effects. We found that awards significantly enhance the post-award impact of papers by both prizewinners and their collaborators. Our mediation model indicates that 78.2% of the effects on collaborators’ papers are direct, while 21.8% are mediated through collaboration networks. We further revealed the exponential nature of the ripple chain along collaboration network.
title: Ripple Effects of Prizewinning in Science

content:
Matched meteorological station data (temperature, precipitation, wind speed, SPEI) from year 2002-2022 to Chinese county boundaries within a set threshold
Utilized Inverse Distance Weighting (IDW) to calculate daily maximum and minimum temperatures, 20h-20h cumulative precipitation, maximum wind speed, and Standardized Precipitation Evapotranspiration Index (SPEI) for each county using ArcGIS, R, and Python
Assigned weights to different climate factors (# of consecutive extreme heat days, # of consecutive extreme cold days, # of rainstorm days, SPEI levels, # of tropical storm days) using Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks (KAN) and empirical methods to construct a county-level climate risk index
Assessed the vulnerability of banks to climate risks across different regions by evaluating their exposure, sensitivity, and adaptive capacity, following the framework established by the IPCC
summary: Duke University, *Supervised by Prof. Junjie Zhang*
title: County-Level Climate Risk Index for Banking System Vulnerability

content:
Investigated the climate risk impact on suppliers and customers and developed effective risk management strategies by constructing the C-Vine-Copula model
Fit the marginal distributions of climate variables and explored the tail dependence between climate risk factors affecting suppliers and the financial performance of customers in the supply-chain networks
Utilized the first-order network coupling and second-order network coupling index to analyze the impact of climate risk on the embeddedness of supply-chain networks, finding extreme high and low temperatures can increase the dispersion of customers within the supply-chain networks
summary: Duke University, *Supervised by Prof. Junjie Zhang*
title: Spillover Effects of Climate Physical Risk on Supply-chain Networks

content:
Utilized bibliometric tools and data science techniques to study variations in the citation impacts across different countries, disciplines, reasons for retraction, open access or not, and institutions ranking (QS).
Applied complex network analysis to assess structural changes in the citation networks among nations before and after retractions, revealing dynamic adjustments in knowledge flows.
Utilized DID and Fixed Effect Regression methodologies to focus on analyzing the impact of retracted papers from China, and identified significant effects within the fields of CS, Engineering, Material Science, and Medicine.
Employed statistical methods and network analysis to investigate the effects of retractions on the previous publications of retracted authors, references within retracted papers, subsequent papers citing the retracted articles, and co-authors’ publications.
Contributed to policy-making by providing empirical evidence used to reform practices surrounding retractions, leading to more robust publication integrity protocols and increased accountability in scholarly communications.
summary: Southern University of Science and Technology, University of Nottingham Ningbo China, *supervised by Prof. Yifang Ma and Prof. Cong Cao*
title: Quantifying the multiscale side-effects of retraction across countries

content:
Investigated the spillover effects and Matthew effects of prizewinning on the citations of both winners and their coauthors’ papers using fixed effect regression analysis techniques to isolate the effects of awards from other variables.
Matched 3 million data points related to the publications and citations of winners and their coauthors using SQL and Python for data manipulation and dynamic matching algorithms.
Identified factors influencing the prizewinning effect on winners and coauthors, including disciplines, award year, publication recency, and award age and winner’s gender by using polynomial regression.
Employed Difference-in-Differences (DID) method to analyze the individual treatment effect of prizewinning, utilizing Stata and R for statistical analysis to ensure robustness in the findings.
Analyzed the mediation effects of prizewinning on coauthors’ papers via winner-coauthor network ties, employing network analysis tools such as Gephi and Python's NetworkX library to visualize and quantify network changes.
Authored the paper “Ripple effects of prizewinning in science,” as the first author.
summary: Indiana University, Bloomington, Southern University of Science and Technology, *supervised by Prof. Santo Fortunato and Prof.Yifang Ma*
title: Ripple Effects of Prizewinning in Science

content:
Developed a two-stage geopolitical risk analysis approach, integrating statistics, econometrics, macroeconomics, and behavioral finance theories, to analyze the transmission mechanisms of geopolitical risk to the oil market.
Collected oil-related data from Thomson Reuters, WIND, Federal Reserve Bank of St.Louis, and U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA), enabling rapid collection and extraction of valid data.
Utilized the time-varying parametric vector autoregressive (TVPVAR) model to demonstrate how geopolitical risk influences oil prices through various transmission paths, including micro and macro media—including oil supply, demand, inventory, speculative behavior, and economic activity.
Demonstrated that speculative behavior intensifies during periods of elevated geopolitical risk, significantly impacting oil prices through fluctuations in market positions (long and short).
Identified that the predominant effect of geopolitical tensions is to drive up oil prices by dampening economic activity, establishing a critical pathway of influence.
Co-published the paper Transmission Mechanisms of Geopolitical Risks to the Crude Oil Market—a pioneering two-stage geopolitical risk analysis approach as the first author.
summary: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, *Supervised by Prof. Song Jiang and Prof. Liwei Xu*
title: Transmission Mechanism of Geopolitical Risks on the Energy Market.

content: Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.    Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.   Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.
summary: This paper establishes a two-stage approach for the first time to analyze the indirect geopolitical risk transmission mechanisms, and applies the time-varying parametric vector autoregressive (TVPVAR) model to illustrate how geopolitical risk affects oil prices via different transmission paths including micro media (supply, demand, inventories, speculative behaviors) and macro media (global economic activities).
title: Transmission Mechanisms of Geopolitical Risks to the Crude Oil Market -- A Pioneering Two-Stage Geopolitical Risk Analysis Approach

content:
Utilized a combination of Random Forest, Decision Tree, Gradient Boosting Tree, and Graph Attention Network models within the conformal prediction framework to forecast oil prices. Incorporated geopolitical factors for enhanced insights into energy market dynamics.
Developed aggregation functions to integrate multiple predictions, facilitating statistical inference and the construction of prediction intervals for future oil prices, with an emphasis on managing uncertainty.
summary: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, *Supervised by Prof. Song Jiang and Prof. Liwei Xu*
title: Conformal Prediction for Dynamic Time Series of Oil Price

content:
Conducted a comprehensive review of over 20 scholarly papers focused on the application of evolutionary and behavioral game-theoretic models in developing strategies for low-carbon energy trading and enhancing global climate action.
Employed network science techniques to analyze the strategic interactions and commitment levels among countries in international climate change mitigation efforts, mapping complex networks to illustrate these relationships.
Developed data-driven frameworks to summarize how climate-related risks (both physical and transitional) propagate through financial markets, impacting credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks across different geographic regions.
Utilized system dynamics modeling to investigate the cascading effects of extreme climate events on economic growth within interconnected climate-social systems, highlighting the role of network analysis in understanding systemic vulnerabilities and response mechanisms.
summary: University College London, Environmental behavioral economics research group, *supervised by Prof.  Lorenzo Lotti*
title: Application of Game Theory and Network Science in Climate Change Analysis.

content:
Conducted in-depth review of 20+ papers & reports (e.g., WB, IPCC, IMF) on circular economy, energy transition, international energy policy, net zero strategy, and sustainable development.
Analyzed green finance's role in driving renewable energy investment & authored insightful essay on energy transition opportunities & threats, providing recommendations for stakeholders.
summary: University of Edinburgh, *supervised by Prof. Xianfeng Fan*
title: Management of Energy Systems for Sustainable Development.

content:
Developed a robust logistic regression method based on non-convex penalty regression by introducing a mean-shift parameter, improving predictive performance significantly,
Assisted to design an innovative iteration-based threshold embedded [Θ-IPOD] algorithm for concurrent outlier detection and robust parameter estimation.
Designed and administered a survey comprising 490 responses to investigate consumer purchasing tendencies and influencing factors within the influencer economy.
Explored factors affecting consumer decision-making in the influencer economy, including personal characteristics, awareness of influencers and their products, purchasing behavior, and factors considered during influencer recommendations.
Conducted an in-depth data analysis using backward stepwise regression to select relevant variables and robust logistic regression algorithms to assess factors influencing consumer purchase behavior regarding web celebrity products, focusing on Organization and Management.
Employed advanced statistical tools and R software to ensure the reliability and effectiveness of the data processing and analysis, demonstrating the robustness and efficacy of the methods in understanding the impact of the web celebrity economy on consumer behavior.
Co-authored the paper “基于非凸惩罚回归的稳健Logistic回归模型及其实证” as the lead author.

Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
On this page, you'll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.
Examples Code Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
```python import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head() ```  renders as
import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head()  Math Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.
Example math block:
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |} {\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$  renders as
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$
Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.
Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\ 1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$  renders as
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$
Diagrams Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.
An example flowchart:
```mermaid graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2] ```  renders as
graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2]  An example sequence diagram:
```mermaid sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good! ```  renders as
sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good!  An example Gantt diagram:
```mermaid gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d ```  renders as
gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d  An example class diagram:
```mermaid classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() } ```  renders as
classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() }  An example state diagram:
```mermaid stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*] ```  renders as
stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*]  Todo lists You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:
- [x] Write math example - [x] Write diagram example - [ ] Do something else  renders as
 Write math example Write diagram example Do something else  Tables Represent your data in tables:
| First Header | Second Header | | ------------- | ------------- | | Content Cell | Content Cell | | Content Cell | Content Cell |  renders as
   First Header Second Header     Content Cell Content Cell   Content Cell Content Cell    Asides Academic supports a shortcode for asides, also referred to as notices, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.
{{% alert note %}} A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers. {{% /alert %}}  renders as

from IPython.core.display import Image Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')  print("Welcome to Academic!")  Welcome to Academic!  Install Python and JupyterLab Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.
Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.
Create or upload a Jupyter notebook Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:
mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ jupyter lab index.ipynb  The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.
Edit your post metadata The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata (front matter).
In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:
--- title: My post's title date: 2019-09-01 # Put any other Academic metadata here... ---  Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.
To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post's folder.
For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.
Convert notebook to Markdown jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.  Example This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter
